Healthy: Your plant looks vibrant! Continue with standard watering and sunlight.
Late Blight: Remove and destroy affected leaves immediately.
Apply a copper-based fungicide or a homemade Bordeaux mixture.
Improve air circulation around the plant.
Powdery Mildew: Mix 1 tablespoon of baking soda and a few drops of liquid soap in 1 liter of water. Spray thoroughly.
Spider Mites: Use a strong jet of water to physically dislodge the pests.
Apply insecticidal soap, focusing on the undersides of leaves.
Aphids: Spray foliage with a mixture of water and mild dish soap (1 tsp per liter) to dislodge aphids.
Introduce natural predators like ladybugs or lacewings.
Bacterial Spot: Remove infected leaves and avoid wetting foliage when watering.
Apply copper-based treatments and sanitize pruning tools between cuts.
Leaf Spot: Remove and discard affected leaves to reduce spread.
Avoid overhead watering and improve drainage around plants.
Rust: Remove infected leaves and dispose of them away from the garden.
Spray with a baking soda solution (1 tbsp per liter) or use neem oil.
Blight (Early Blight): Practice crop rotation and remove plant debris from the soil.
Mulch to prevent soil splash and apply tomato-safe fungicide if needed.
Root Rot: Stop watering and let the soil dry; repot into fresh, well-draining soil if roots are rotting.
Improve drainage and avoid waterlogged conditions.
Fusarium Wilt: Remove and destroy heavily infected plants; use resistant varieties where possible.
Solarize the soil and avoid replanting susceptible crops in the same spot for a season.
Nutrient Deficiency (General): Add balanced compost or a slow-release organic fertilizer to the soil.
Perform a soil test to identify specific deficiencies (e.g., nitrogen, iron, magnesium).
Nitrogen Deficiency: Apply a nitrogen-rich organic fertilizer such as blood meal or composted manure.
Mulch with nitrogen-rich green materials (e.g., grass clippings).
Iron Chlorosis: Lower soil pH for iron-absorbing plants by adding elemental sulfur or organic matter like peat moss.
Use chelated iron as a foliar spray for quick correction.
Mosaic Virus: Remove and destroy infected plants; control aphid vectors.
Sanitize tools and practice good hygiene to prevent spread.
Thrips: Use sticky traps and spray insecticidal soap on affected areas.
Introduce predatory insects like minute pirate bugs where possible.
Whiteflies: Use yellow sticky traps and spray with neem oil to control populations.
Remove heavily infested leaves and improve air circulation.
Scale Insects: Gently remove scales with a cotton swab dipped in rubbing alcohol.
Apply horticultural oil to suffocate remaining pests.
Powdery Mildew (Severe): Prune to increase airflow and remove heavily infected tissue.
Apply milk spray (1 part milk to 9 parts water) weekly as a preventive treatment.
